text: today on x cast president obama urges
congress to take up immigration reform
everybody recognizes the system's broken
the question is will we finally summon
the political will to do something about
it but one state isn't waiting for the
federal government to act Arizona has
really been striking out on its own
coming up with its own fixes in Syria
one man has become the focal point of
the protesters economic grievances Rami
Makhlouf is arguably serious most
powerful businessmen and in China
farmers are asked to stop selling
Jasmine the revolutionary symbol of the
Tunisian uprising what we really need to
do is to keep up the fight to pass
genuine comprehensive reform that is the
ultimate solution to this problem that's
what I'm committed to doing one of the
things that President Obama has talked a
great deal about is comprehensive
immigration reform that's going to be a
tough sell here in Arizona where there's
a sense that there are too many illegal
immigrants in the state Arizona has
really been striking out on its own
coming up with its own fixes there was
SB 1070 the illegal immigrant bill the
legislature did two things recently that
also are controversial they decided they
are going to build their own border wall
to block Mexico from the United States
and then second proposal is the
legislature has given the governor the
ability to create an Arizona guard
different from the national guard that
some sort of a militia unit that the
governor could call out and one of its
purposes would be to steal the border
there's no money for that it's really
symbolic but it really gets to the point
that Arizona has been acting on its own
nobody believes that anything is going
to get done on immigration before the
president
election so this is really something
that the president is talking about to
prepare for a campaign it's easier for
politicians to defer the problem until
the next election and there's always the
next election Hispanic voters are
extremely important in presidential
campaigns and President Obama is
reaching out to them and that was one of
the purposes of his remarks today a
serious uprising entered its eighth week
government crackdown escalated in cities
and towns across the country government
officials have cast the uprising as an
armed uprising one led by militant
Islamists with support from abroad but
even they acknowledge what they call
legitimate demands economic and
political grievances have gone
unaddressed four years in Syria some of
those economic grievances revolve around
a figure who's at the Nexus of clan
loyalty absolute power and the uprising
itself his name is rami Makhlouf Syria's
most prominent businessmen and one of
its most powerful figures makhlouf is
more than a businessman no he's the
cousin of President Bashar al-assad and
part of a ruling elite in one respect or
another that has been in power in the
country for more than four decades that
ruling elite is a tight-knit group it's
staffed by many of the contemporaries of
President Bashar al-assad but also many
of his relatives his brother is the head
of the Republican Guard his
brother-in-law is the deputy chief of
staff of the army mr. Makhlouf brother
himself is the head of intelligence in
Damascus it's a group that mr. Makhlouf
says works together talks often and will
often come up with joint decisions I
went to Syria yesterday for a brief
visit ostensibly to see mr. Makhlouf the
interview was scheduled for the
afternoon and I arrived a little early
crossing the Lebanese border into Syria
where Mr Mac loose aids escorted me to
Damascus the road to Damascus at least
about an hour away from the Lebanese
border was quiet there was no sign of
checkpoints no military escalation and
no buildup in the capital itself indeed
the capital seemed tranquil even
ordinary well it was only a glimpse of
the capital the iconography of the
regime was clear the message it's been
trying to send out to the world for past
days and weeks it's either us or chaos
and posters in the capital set us a
message noted discord and no to conflict
and in China the flower jasmine has
become a problematic symbol in the last
few months as revolution
and unrest took hold in the Arab world
in North Africa Chinese government has
been increasingly nervous their fears
intensified in February when calls went
out on the internet anonymously for
Chinese people to stage their own
Jasmine Revolution they took that phrase
from Tunisia where revolutionaries
they're called their revolt the jasmine
revolution since then the government has
waged this assault on anything Jasmine
related blocking it in searches on the
chinese internet text messages with the
word jasmine have often been blocked and
also banning the sale of livejasmin
plants the ban has not been publicly
announced but I visited a half dozen
flower markets around Beijing over the
last few weeks and I could not find any
Jasmine over the last few days jasmine
has returned very slowly to the market
mostly because the growers have nowhere
to unload it and so they've been dumping
it at the market very very cheaply but
it was clear that they had been
forbidden from selling it a lot of girls
were asked to sign pledges that they
wouldn't sell it also told to write down
the license plates of anyone who came
asking for Jasmine this episode kind of
highlights how anxious the Chinese
government is about their own hold on
power of the fact that a flower could
make them feel so unsettled I think
highlights their nervousness
you
